subject: Add next url forward
commitMessage:
Add next url forward

Details: https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/issues/28
The app rejects all paths which are not defined in router file
and redirects to 'page not found'

Signed-off-by: Mateusz Gapski <mateuszx.gapski@intel.com>
Change-Id: I0a3232f919d112196cf5b3c5477ba1e9797212d2

Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Overall, I'd much rather see webui-vue obey the "IsAuthenticated" flag like phosphor-webui does, so we can use the next handling from here:

Patch Set 1:

Overally, I'd rather see this patchset add obeying the "IsAuthenticated" flag, so we can use the next url routing from bmcweb:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/35457

Although I understand not wanting to get mixed up in that discussion, as it's quite complex.  Handle the security problems, and the non-javascript route case, and document your testing, and this should be fine.

Patch Set 2:

I think the big requirements from when I built this for phosphor-webui were:
1. It can handle webui route fragments (ex /#sensors).
2. It can handle non-webui routes (ex /redfish/v1)
3. It explicitly rejects URLs that include a domain (ex <mybmc>/login?next="https://www.google.com" should forward to the homepage, or error), not forward to google.

It looks like the patchset currently does #1 only.

I didn't mean to be opaque in my earlier comment about security.  I was lacking in time to type a more complete response.

Patch Set 2:

I'm sorry I forgot write back. I was testing my solution and if I use url <mybmc>/login?next="https://www.google.com" (your 3 point) vuejs redirects to 'page not found' page. 
The similar situation is for your point 2. The route /redvish/v1 is not define in routing file so vuejs framework doesn't find it and redirects to 'page not found' again - I think it is correct.
Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> I'm sorry I forgot write back. I was testing my solution and if I use url <mybmc>/login?next="https://www.google.com" (your 3 point) vuejs redirects to 'page not found' page. 
> The similar situation is for your point 2. The route /redvish/v1 is not define in routing file so vuejs framework doesn't find it and redirects to 'page not found' again - I think it is correct.

It's not correct.  #2 should forward to the redfish route being requested.  Generally you do that by adjusting the window.location parameter, not the js route.  You could detect js routes, and fall back to window.location if the requested url is not a js route, but that seems like overkill.  Once you do that, you'll see the www.google.com example work too, which needs to be mitigated.

1. Do we have to log in via this webui when we are going to redfish page?
2. Does the AngularJS application provide such functionality (redfish redirect after log in)?

There are some redfish API calls that require authentication and the user will be redirected to the login page when the API returns a 401.

> 2. Does the AngularJS application provide such functionality (redfish redirect after log in)?

Yes, the redirect works in the AngularJS application. However, it does not use redfish.

Yes, I saw endpoints but in the comments above I noticed that there is also a redfish portal/documentation (mentioned by Ed Tanous). In my opinion if redfish is a separate website it should not use the authorization mechanisms of this webui. However I understand that this is some kind of shortcut (which also works in previous app). So, should I add a similar modification (like in: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-webui/commit/09081ec7f06491150e90838a4bec53004358db51#diff-ae3386ffce819aa721dc9e50162c293fedad4d65019f4004d4b8b1f5c495eb3a)?

I believe so, we don't want it to be able to redirect to a different domain.

That is a fine opinion to have, and if you'd like to put up patchsets to add separate logins for Redfish, dbus-rest, and IBM management console, I'd accept them, but that adds a lot of complexity for something that's a relatively simple fix.

> However I understand that this is some kind of shortcut (which also works in previous app). So, should I add a similar modification (like in: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-webui/commit/09081ec7f06491150e90838a4bec53004358db51#diff-ae3386ffce819aa721dc9e50162c293fedad4d65019f4004d4b8b1f5c495eb3a)?

You need to do that, as well as using window.location instead of invoking the route handler when you do a "redirect".

(1 comment)

I tried testing by navigating to an authenticated page on the app, cleared my session cookie then clicked the app refresh in the app header. As expected, I was redirected to the login page, I logged in, but then wasn't redirected anywhere. I had to re-enter login credentials a second time to log in

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I apologize for the change in status. After discussing with Yoshie and re-testing, I found a couple issues.

1. Log out from any page but Overview
This results in the URL of that last visited page being added to the URL query string. The user would expect for the the next login to direct them to the overview page.

2. When a time out occurs, tested by removing the cookies, localStorage, and sessionStorage, the URL query string includes login and requires the user to submit their login twice to be directed to the overview page.

Patch Set 5:

> 
> I apologize for the change in status. After discussing with Yoshie and re-testing, I found a couple issues.
> 
> 1. Log out from any page but Overview
> This results in the URL of that last visited page being added to the URL query string. The user would expect for the the next login to direct them to the overview page.
> 
> 2. When a time out occurs, tested by removing the cookies, localStorage, and sessionStorage, the URL query string includes login and requires the user to submit their login twice to be directed to the overview page.

FYI, the way I've tested this in the past on phosphor-webui was to delete the session from the backend.  That exercises different code paths than deleting the session from the browser does.

Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)
Missing testing.

There's security implications of this that looking at the patchset, you haven't understood.  Please think through the possible attack vectors a little, and rework your patch please.

phosphor-webui already has mitigation for these that you can use as an example.
Oops...I think you left in some test code. :)
Done
You're missing several checks here.  Is this a valid url?  Is this a webui-vue route, or a different route?
If the user is explicitly logging out of the app, we probably do not want to add the next url query. Can we add some kind of check?
Is this branch needed at all?  next="/" seems like a valid forward, and doesn't need special cased?
I added this to prevent adding nextUrl parameter when it is no needed. For example, when you go to the website for the first time.
but, isn't it still needed in that case?  If you go to the website for the first time, and you've never logged in, you need to be forwarded to the main page, no?
Why look for "." here?  I'm having trouble understanding what this is looking for.
To avoid being redirected to another domain (ex. google.com)

indexOf('.') isn't an appropriate check for "Is this a relative url".  Routes can definitely contain . in them and still be relative.

I'd recommend copying the check out of phosphor-webui.

Please don't special case this uri.  We support way more urls than just redfish.

I'm not following why we would have this branch and the else line 142 at all.  Sure, window.location forces a reload of the webui, but that seems like a good thing, no?
I want to distinguish which link refers to webui and which link to another page (different routing mechanism). Are there other (than redfish) subpages that use this login mechanism.

Correct, there are more URIs that just redfish that use this login.  Phosphor-webui solved a similar problem, I'd recommend looking at the code.  The solution there was to just set window.location in all cases, and while that results in a reload in the webui case, that reload is a good thing overall.

The concern here is that redfish is not the only url that would require support. Phosphor-webui used the Angular $location service to test for the query string. 

You can take a look here: 
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-webui/blob/d10511f2a7fc07910d7ca517bd73331763322fa0/app/login/controllers/login-controller.js#L42-L48
Need to verify this isn't redirecting off the machine.  when phosphor-webui for how it does this.
This comment wasn't answered.
Couldn't this branch be removed entirely?
I added this after Yoshie Muranaka review to prevent displaying next url after logging out.
what does searching next for : do here?

As per your suggestion, I copied it from the phosphor-webui. It validates that the user does not go to another domain.
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-webui/blob/d10511f2a7fc07910d7ca517bd73331763322fa0/app/login/controllers/login-controller.js#L42-L48

Interesting;  That got changed from the original here:
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-webui/commit/09081ec7f06491150e90838a4bec53004358db51

Although the new code looks wrong, I suspect we should've been checking for both.

With that said, I guess this is fine as-is then, given that it was just copied out of phosphor-webui.

I talked to James a little about this, and I guess Intel fixed this locally and never updated the patch.   We should be doing something like this:

https://github.com/Intel-BMC/phosphor-webui/blob/2397c142c0d75c7705757a52848945b00928232d/app/login/controllers/login-controller.js#L34

Basically, checking for any special characters in the result.
If you reverse this condition and use return, code will be easier to read. Also you may find that some conditions can be joined 😊
adding return enable you to remove else
the goal of this function is to find  url and than call this.$router.push
This is still an issue.  Not all webserver paths are defined in the router file.  If they're not defined in the router file, it should be forwarded to window.location.

Why did this change?  I'm reading this as

"if the server returns unauthorized, go to the homepage" which doesn't seem right.
Router automatically replaces slash with the login route, but fixed for better code readability
